@the-leafhopper contact meredithjunewillmott@gmail com 1 who is the cobalt blue milkweed beetle oregon contains an incredible ecotype diversity from green forests to sandy deserts this diversity brings a high diversity of plant life and thus a high diversity of things that feed on plant life among all the leaf-feeding insects one family rises above the rest the chrysomelidae commonly known as leaf beetles this group comprises over 37 000 globally distributed species and contains everything from the pea and bean weevils to the tortoise beetles to the focus of this hat the genus chrysocus the two species in this genus chrysocus auratus and chrysocus cobaltinus are so closely related that they can interbreed when co-occurring but typically c cobaltinus the cobalt milkweed beetle prefers higher and drier climates this beetle can be found from british columbia to new mexico with many observations on inaturalist recorded in oregon making it the perfect choice for a local insect to feature on a hat the cobalt milkweed beetle feeds on its namesake- milkweed- and gets its name both from its food source and its electric blue coloring these beetles can range from a bright jewel blue to a darker navy tone but are easy to spot on milkweed plants or occasionally feeding on dogbane feeding on milkweed is no easy task- the plant produces cardenolide- toxic substances that quickly kill most animals unlucky enough to take a bite these beetles along with a few other insects- such as monarch butterfly caterpillars have adjusted to their unwilling host plants through adapting to the toxic sap the cobalt milkweed beetle has a single mutation in one of their proteins that blocks the uptake of cardenolide and allows the beetle to ingest the toxin safely and more than ingest safely the cobalt milkweed beetles contains specialized glands on their wing covers elytra that sequester cardenolides allowing the beetles to release toxins when threatened when you find one cobalt milkweed beetle you may just find two mating in this group is a terrifically long affair- both males and females are polygamous so males and females will seek out multiple partners but once a male has found a female he will mount here and couple for around 20 minutes after this 20 minutes of activity has concluded he will remain on her back in a behavior theorized to protect his chances of paternity the female is still able to move around with him attached and does so for around 2 hours at this point he decides he s as likely as he will be to father some new cobalt milkweed beetles and drops off to seek out his next mate but he s not just annoying her- some research suggests that riding around on her back can protect her from predation if you happen to be around a patch of milkweed during
